awd_titl_txt: Measuring Sulfuric Acid Nucleation Potential to Develop a Generalized, Semi-Empirical Nucleation Model for the Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to holistically examine how complex mixtures of gases react with sulfuric acid to form new particles and to develop a simple framework and model for predicting this process. The new model will particle formation on the basis of characteristics of the gaseous mixture, rather than a complete set of chemical reactions. A complementary instrument will be developed measure the potential of a mixture to form new particles as well. The combination of this model and measurement suite will simplify representation of particle formation in large scale atmospheric models in an affordable and robust method. This will provide insights into particle formation - one of the greatest uncertainties in existing atmospheric models. Particles formation impacts other important processes including the transmission and absorption of light and cloud formation and properties.

The project will directly support a female junior faculty member, one graduate student, and the incorporation of particle formation concepts into a series of atmospheric chemistry workshops for elementary school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric nucleation produces the majority of seed particles for cloud droplet formation. As a result, understanding the chemical reactions behind atmospheric nucleation is critical in modeling how clouds influence the rate at which climate is changing. Atmospheric nucleation predominately involves sulfuric acid reacting with a wide range of compounds in the air, including atmospheric bases like ammonia, methylamine, dimethylamine, and trimethylamine. This project examined two aspects of atmospheric nucleation: (1) quantifying various reactions that enhance or suppress sulfuric acid nucleation and (2) developing and validating a semi-empirical reaction model for sulfuric acid nucleating in the complex atmosphere that can be used to predict atmospheric nucleation rates.

Chemical Reactions contributing to atmospheric nucleation: During this project, reactions that enhance and suppress sulfuric acid nucleation were investigated.  Gaseous compounds were mixed in a flow reactor and produced molecular clusters, and freshly formed particles were measured with a mass spectrometer and condensation particle counter. We have shown that sulfuric acid does not nucleate with small organic acids, including oxalic and formic acids. These acids are extremely prevalent in the atmosphere, often 1,000 to 10,000 times higher in concentration than sulfuric acid.  As such, small organic acids do not need to be considered in atmospheric nucleation models. In contrast, methanesulfonic acid synergistically enhanced nucleation with sulfuric acid and methylamine with observed formation rates higher than the combined methanesulfonic acid-methylamine and sulfuric acid-methylamine rates. This suggests that these three compounds form more stable particles together than any combination of the two. Methanesulfonic acid was also found to suppress sulfuric acid-trimethylamine nucleation, likely due to the bulkiness of a methane sulfonic acid-trimethylamine cluster which prevents the other molecules from growing the cluster into a larger particle.

Nucleation Potential Model for atmospheric nucleation: From these measurements, the Nucleation Potential Model (NPM) was developed to describe how sulfuric acid nucleates in a complex reactive system like the atmosphere. The NPM combines the contributions of all stabilizing compounds into an effective base concentration, [Beff]. [Beff] gives higher weight to more potent nucleating agents, like dimethylamine, by increasing their contribution to [Beff] and lower [Beff] for weaker stabilizing compounds. We demonstrated that [Beff] can be quantified by reacting sampled air with a known concentration of sulfuric acid in a specific amount of time and measuring the resulting concentration of freshly produced 1-nm particles. We collaborated with Aerosol Dynamics Inc. to develop a water-based condensation particle counter to detect 1-nm particles with fast time resolution. [Beff] was quantified for laboratory-generated mixtures of stabilizing compounds containing ten unique compounds and Pittsburgh, PA air. Observations of [Beff] for the various sampled gases indicate that [Beff] scales by the concentration of strong bases, specifically dimethylamine and trimethylamine, and is reduced with increasing relative humidity.

Intellectual Merit: As research continues to expand the list of potential sulfuric acid stabilizing compounds, it is clear that modeling and measuring all possible nucleation reactions is impossible due to the sheer complexity of the atmosphere. Furthermore, to represent nucleation accurately, regional and global atmospheric models would require long-term and high spatial resolution measurements of reactant compounds, which are currently furnished by expensive, high-resolution mass spectrometers. This project addresses these two key needs by providing an implementable model that accounts for the complex nucleation reactions and an affordable measurement technique to quantify the effective concentration of stabilizing compounds in the atmosphere.

Broader Impacts: This project produced NPM, an easy-to-implement nucleation model that can be used in large-scale atmospheric models. Results from this project, including fundamental nucleation, aerosol science, and climate science concepts, were incorporated into atmospheric chemistry workshops for ~70 students in 3rd-5th graders taught by the Jen Lab in partnership with the Gelfand Outreach Center at Carnegie Mellon University. In addition, the Jen Lab partnered with two local high school chemistry teachers to develop an atmospheric science curriculum. The teachers spent a summer researching atmospheric ion chemistry in the Jen Lab and organizing course materials. Topics covered include energy, albedo, greenhouse gases, heat transfer, and mass spectrometry. Each lesson plan was designed to be independent. This provided flexibility for the teachers to incorporate the lesson plans into their pre-existing curriculum. The curriculum was deployed in their classes, and feedback was gathered to improve the education materials for the following school year.
